definition: Shi Lang (1621-1696), Chinese admiral who served under the Ming and Qing Dynasties
surname Shi
to grant/to give/to bestow/to act/to carry out
jade-like stone/clean and white/tinkling of pendants

sentences.english: Shi Lang will sail into a Pacific Ocean teeming with carriers.
sentences.chinese: “施琅”將去航母如雲的太平洋巡邏。

sentences.english: For Shi Lang, China reportedly purchased turbines from Ukraine.
sentences.chinese: 據報道，“施琅號”渦輪發動機採購自烏克蘭。

sentences.english: On the surface, Shi Lang will be all but defenseless, by U.S. standards.
sentences.chinese: 按照美國標準，“施琅”在水面上的防禦非常低。

sentences.english: The name Shi Lang could also be translated as "big fat target."
sentences.chinese: 施琅號應該被翻譯成“肥大的活靶子”。

definition: Koxinga (1624-1662), military leader
Shen Baozhen (1820-1879), Qing Minister of the Navy, founded Fuzhou Naval College 船政學堂|船政学堂[Chuan2 zheng4 Xue2 tang2] in 1866
Wu Sangui (1612-1678), Chinese general who let the Manchus into China and helped them establish the Qing Dynasty, later leading a revolt against Qing in an effort to start his own dynasty
Ding Ruchang (1836-1895), commander of the Qing North China Navy
the Qing army
Dorgon (1612-1651), fourteenth son of Nurhaci 努爾哈赤|努尔哈赤, successful general, instrumental in Manchu conquest of China, ruled China as regent 1644-1650 for his nephew Emperor Shunzhi 順治帝
Qi Jiguang (1528-1588), military leader

Hong Taiji (1592-1643), eighth son of Nurhaci 努爾哈赤|努尔哈赤, reigned 1626-1636 as Second Khan of Later Jin dynasty 後金|后金, then founded the Qing dynasty 大清 and reigned 1636-1643 as Emperor/posthumous name 清太宗
the Qing court (as government of China)
Zuo Zongtang (1812-1885), Chinese administrator and military leader
Three feudatories rebellion against Qing 1673-1681 during the reign of Kangxi
Yi Sunshin (1545-1598), Korean admiral and folk hero, famous for sea victories over the Japanese invaders
Chongzhen, reign name of last Ming emperor (1628-1644)
the local commander/provincial governor (in Qing and Ming times)
Khubilai Khan (1215-1294), grandson of Genghis Khan 成吉思汗, first Yuan dynasty emperor, reigned 1260-1294
Li Hung-chang or Li Hongzhang (1823-1901), Qing dynasty general, politician and diplomat
